author: modernlegend.
content: Got it, thank you! And when it's time for a node to execute the transactions of the newest mined block (that has been approved by the network), for each transaction, I imagine the node is loading into memory the state of the two accounts involved (i.e. an EOA transferring ether to another EOA, or an EOA calling a function in a contract account), executing the relevant code, causing state transition, and then persisting the state changes to disk (e.g. persisting new account balances or contract state). Is that right?

author: jammutkarsh
content:
Hey, I being learning about roll ups in ETH, and what in simple terms i can conclude its functioning is like git/github. we creates a project(a blockchain like ETH). Create a branch(the roll ups){branch in branch is also possible}{Layer 2 and so on }, test features(Validate small transactions of EThH or data). Then when the process is complete you merge the sub branch to the master branch(Layer 1 of ETH). 

Correct me if I am wrong?

author: .themystery
content: I was going through ERC777. But couldn't figure out if there is a way to find which token is received is received by a contract through the data received in the tokensReceived hook?

author: jgm
content:
`msg.sender` will be the address of the token contract.

(Note that this is not really an R&D question; you'd be better off in the CryptoDevs discord)

author: modernlegend.
content: Hey guys, question about smart contract destruction. I read that the original author can destroy any smart contracts they created with a "SELFDESTRUCT" opcode.  Wouldn't this be a vector for malicious activity? Presumably most participants engaged in such contracts are not considering the option of the author destroying the contract and its associated state, which could potentially wipe funds the participants had believed to be securely held in escrow via the contract.
